awd_titl_txt: RUI: SusChEM: Towards accurate computational dynamical and mechanistic studies of transition metal homogeneous (photo)catalysis
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Catalysis Program and the Chemical Theory, Models and Computational Methods Program of the Division of Chemistry, Professor Hendrik Eshuis of Montclair State University is applying and developing computational methods to study the catalysis of chemical reactions using metal complexes and to understand the relationship between the structure of molecules and their activity as catalysts.  A computational method, called the Random Phase Approximation Method, is being developed and refined to described fundamental aspects of how chemical bonds are activated by catalysts. This method is also being applied to study how light can drive certain catalysts to perform specific reactions, also known as photocatalysis.  This project is contributing to the toolbox of computational methods available for the study of a wide range of chemistries, including catalysis.  Ultimately, it may advance the development of more efficient and greener catalysts, a goal of interest to both society and industry. Both undergraduate and graduate students are involved in this research, and Prof. Eshuis is involved in strengthening the computational chemistry component of the chemistry curriculum at Montclair State University.

Prof. Eshuis is applying and developing computational methods to study transition metal homogeneous (photo)catalysis and is primarily focused on the development of the random phase approximation method to describe dynamic and mechanistic aspects of bond activation reactions.  The quality of the random phase approximation method is being benchmarked against experimental results and compared to other ab initio and density functional theory methods. The method is being applied to the study of mechanisms of carbon-carbon bond activation reactions by nickel containing catalysts, with a focus on the link between ligand composition and reactivity, as well as in the study of the mechanism of photocatalyzed trifluoromethylation reactions.  The random phase approximation method is being further developed to be used in ab initio molecular dynamical studies of mechanisms involving carbon-hydrogen bond activation and extended to open-shell systems.

por.por_cntn:
A key goal of this work is the assessment of the random phase approximation (RPA)nmethod for transition metal chemistry. Transition metal chemistry is much harder to describe computationally than main-groupchemistry due to the filled d- or f-sublevels. Popular density functionals often fail to describe transition metal chemistry accurately or systematically. There is thus a need for a reliable alternative. Over the past decade, the RPA method has gained popularity as a viable and efficient alternative and it was shown to be accurate for main-group elements.

The most significant scientific outcome of this project is the benchmarking of the RPA method for homogeneous transition metal chemistry. Through careful comparison to experiment and to high-level theory for a wide range of realistic catalytic systems including complete mechanisms (with intermediates and transition states) we demonstrated that RPA yields results of the same accuracy as popular density functionals and in addition behaves more systematically accross the mechanism. RPA yields errors of about 2-5 kcal/mol for energies and can be concluded to be an independent alternative and complement to density functional theory.

A second outcome is the development and application of ab initio molecular dynamics using RPA. This method can be used to study the dynamic properties of systems, such as finite temperature effects and/or vibrational motion. Unfortunately, the use of ab initio molecular dynamics with RPA for transition metal clusters is not yet practical due to the large associated computational cost. We therefore are applying the method to small systems involving main-group elements only.

A major outcome of this grant is the impact on the students who worked on the project. Over the course of the project more than 10 undergraduate students and 1 graduate students have made significant contributions to the project. In return, the students have benefitted from being part of a research group and from being mentored by the PI. For all students this was their first exposure to fundamental research and as such a real eye-opener. The project thus contributed to increasing science literacy amongst the student population. The students developed their research skills and critical thinking abilities as well as their presentation skills. These skills will serve them well no matter which career path they take.
